flawed_nl_solution:
The sum of the ratios representing the amount of money the three has is 4+5+6=<<4+5+6=51>>51
If the total amount of money they have is $75, the amount of money Cara has represented by the fraction 4/51 is 4/51*$75=$100/17<<4/51*75=100/17>>100/17
Similarly, the amount of money Janet has represented by the fraction 5/51 of the total ratio is 5/51*$75=$125/17<<5/51*75=125/17>>125/17
Combined, Cara and Janet have $100/17+125/17=$225/17<<100/17+125/17=225/17>>225/17
If Cara and Janet buy goods worth $225/17 and sells them at 80% of the buying price, the selling price of the goods will be 80/100*$225/17=$180/17<<225/17*80/100=180/17>>180/17
Since they bought the goods at $225/17 and sold them at $180/17, Janet and Cara would run at a loss of $225/17-$180/17=$45/17<<225/17-180/17=45/17>>45/17
#### 45/17

error_details.explanation: The result of this computation should be 15, not 51. It appears two adjacent digits were swapped.
